Crime_Name: Forfeiture of guarantee under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over enforcement of financial guarantee
Legal_Issue: Whether CBSA breached procedural fairness by refusing to extend time for submissions
Evidence_Assessment: Initial CBSA letter lacked sufficient details; complexity of case required more time
Decision_Outcome: CBSA's decision set aside; judicial review allowed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Credibility_Factor: Etienne's request for extension based on need for more information and time
Legal_Rule: Guarantors must be given a reasonable opportunity to make submissions before enforcement
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of reasonable extension rendered right to respond illusory
Outcome_on_Merits: CBSA found to have breached procedural fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: CBSA's initial notice, Etienne's request for 90-day extension, lack of detailed information
Legal_Framework: Principles of procedural fairness and natural justice
Defendant_Response: CBSA denied extension and enforced the $15,000 guarantee
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of CBSA decision, opportunity to submit response
Outcome: Court granted judicial review and allowed more time for response

Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over enforcement of financial guarantee due to non-compliance

Legal_Rule: Duty of procedural fairness requires reasonable opportunity to respond
Grounds_for_Claim: Extension request denied, undermining ability to meaningfully participate

Defendant_Response: CBSA enforced the $15,000 guarantee without granting extension
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, set aside enforcement decision, allow time to respond
Outcome: Federal Court allowed application, decision set aside

Crimes.Crime_Name: Importing cocaine contrary to Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 challenge
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Appeal Division's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Sentence imposed vs. time served
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish jurisdiction and Charter breach
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 64(2) IRPA excludes appeal rights if punished by at least two years imprisonment; Charter s. 7 does not protect non-citizens from deportation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misinterpretation of 'punished' and alleged Charter violation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction under IRPA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Three-year sentence for importing cocaine, six months actually served
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued that 'punished' should mean time served and that s. 64(2) violates Charter s. 7
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of deportation order and IRPA provision
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; questions certified for appeal

Legal_Issue: Whether Section 22 of the Trademarks Act can be used as a ground for opposition in trademark registration proceedings
Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review of Trademarks Opposition Board Decision
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside, matter referred back for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must be satisfied they are entitled to use the trademark under Section 30(i)
Legal_Rule: Section 38(2)(a) allows opposition based on non-compliance with Section 30(i); Section 22 prohibits use of trademarks likely to depreciate goodwill
Standard_of_Review: Error of law and failure to consider relevant jurisprudence
Grounds_for_Claim: Parmalat sought to include Section 22 as a ground for opposing Sysco's 'BLACK DIAMOND' trademark application
Legal_Framework: Sections 22, 30(i), and 38(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act
Defendant_Response: Sysco's response not detailed, but tribunal rejected inclusion of Section 22 as valid ground
Remedy_Requested: Amendment of opposition statement to include Section 22 as ground
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case referred back
Legal_Provision: Section 22, Section 30(i), Section 38(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act
Authority: Trademarks Opposition Board, Federal Court (on judicial review)
